Writing Custom CML Files

Creating C++ packages can be difficult to navigate for first-time users of ROS2. This tutorial will explain the basic structure of a CMakeLists.txt file, otherwise known as a CML file. Importantly, we will cover how to properly compile and link pacakages with several files and subdirectories found in the include/ and src/ directories of the ROS2 package.

First, we want to guarantee compatibilty by enforcing a lower bound on the CMake version. For example, RoboFlock uses CMake version 3.8, so the first line of the CML file should be:

1cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 3.8)

In the context of ROS2, the project name should be the extactly the same as the package name created in the ROS2 environment. Let’s call our project hello_world_pkg and assume it has the following directory structure:

.
├── build
├── install
├── log
└── src
    ├── build
    ├── hello_world_pkg
    │   ├── include
    │   │   └── hello_world_pkg
    │   │       ├── greetings
    │   │       └── salutations
    │   └── src
    │       ├── greetings
    │       └── salutations
    ├── install
    └── log

We can use the project() command to give our project a name and to set environmental variables for the absolute paths to the source and binary directories.

2project(hello_world_pkg)

The next few lines set parameters for the compiler, such as the C++ standard being used and various compiler flags.

3if(NOT CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD)
4    set(CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD 14)
5endif()
6
7if(CMAKE_COMPILER_IS_GNUCXX OR CMAKE_CXX_COMPILER_ID MATCHES "Clang")
8    add_compile_options(-Wall -Wextra -Wpedantic)
9endif()

ROS2 allows for a complex network of packages and nodes to interact with one another, and as such, we need to tell the build process what packages have dependencies. In our project, we will use three built-in ROS2 packages (ament_cmake, rclcpp, and std_msgs) that are needed for most of RoboFlock’s nodes.

10# Creates variables like rclcpp_LIBRARIES and and std_msgs_INCLUDE_DIRS
11#
12find_package(ament_cmake REQUIRED) # ROS2 build system
13find_package(rclcpp REQUIRED)      # ROS2 C++ client library
14find_package(std_msgs REQUIRED)    # ROS2 standard msg types

Now that we have our compatibility requirements, we need to make sure that the compiler can find all our files and properly link libraries. First, let’s tell the compiler where to search for included files:

15# Adds include/ directory to compiler's search path for ALL targets
16#   This allows for the preprocessor directive "#include" to work properly for our code
17#
18include_directories(
19    include
20)

Next, we’ll handle our source files. We can organize all the source files into a single variable so that we don’t have to repeat commands and file names for every single source file. For extra precaution, we’ll ensure that these files exist. The code in our CML file should look like this:

21# Creates the variable LIB_SOURCE_FILES used to organize source files for the library
22#
23set(LIB_SOURCE_FILES
24    src/greetings/hello_source1.cpp
25    src/greetings/hello_source2.cpp
26    src/salutations/goodbye_source1.cpp
27    src/salutations/goodbye_source2.cpp
28)
29
30# Loop through each file in LIB_SOURCE_FILES to make sure that they exist
31#
32foreach(src_file ${LIB_SOURCE_FILES})
33    if(NOT EXISTS ${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR}/${src_file})
34        message(WARNING "Source file not found: ${src_file}")
35    else()
36        message(STATUS "Found source file: ${src_file}")
37    endif()
38endforeach()

Libraries are collections of pre-written code that help with code reusability and scalability. There are a few different types of libraries that we can make:

  • Static libraries contain compiled code of all the files and are linked directly to an executable at compile time.

  • Shared (Dynamic) libraries contain compiled code only for required files and are loaded at runtime

Let’s add a library target to be built from the source files and then link everything together. The heavy-lifters here will be the target_include_directories() and target_link_libraries() commands. We can use the PUBLIC keyword to make our custom library visible to other packages, allowing it to be added as a dependency:

39# Create the library target
40#
41add_library(${PROJECT_NAME}_lib ${LIB_SOURCE_FILES})
42
43# Add the include path to the library target
44#   PUBLIC indicates that both the library target and anything linking to it gets these includes
45#
46target_include_directories(${PROJECT_NAME}_lib PUBLIC
47    include
48)
49
50# Tell the linker which specific libraries to use when linking the target and its dependents
51#   Usage requirements are propagated
52#
53target_link_libraries(${PROJECT_NAME}_lib PUBLIC
54    ${rclcpp_LIBRARIES}
55    ${std_msgs_LIBRARIES}
56)

In order to run our ROS2 node, we’re going to need an executable:

57# Add an executable target to be built from our node's source code
58#
59add_executable(hello_world_node src/hello_world_node.cpp)
60
61# Tell the compiler what include directories we want to use
62#   PRIVATE indicates that our include/ directory is only available to our source code and is not propagated to other targets
63#
64target_include_directories(hello_world_node PRIVATE include)
65
66# Tell the linker which specific libraries to use when linking the executable target
67#   Usage requirements are propagated
68#
69target_link_libraries(hello_world_node PUBLIC
70    ${PROJECT_NAME}_lib
71    rclcpp::rclcpp
72    ${std_msgs_TARGETS}
73)

The CML file should specify where our libraries and executable are being installed by generating a set of rules using the install() command. We’ll also create static and shared libraries and executables that can be used by other packages:

74# Specify that our node's executable and custom library will be installed into lib/hello_world_pkg
75#   Then, we'll specify options for our output artifacts (compiled binaries generated during the build process)
76install(TARGETS
77    hello_world_node
78    ${PROJECT_NAME}_lib
79    DESTINATION lib/${PROJECT_NAME}
80    ARCHIVE DESTINATION lib         # Static libraries (.a)
81    LIBRARY DESTINATION lib         # Shared libraries (.so)
82    RUNTIME DESTINATION bin         # Executables
83)
84
85# Specify that our custom include files will be installed in include
86install(DIRECTORY include/
87    DESTINATION include/
88)

Note: the paths provided here are relative to the project’s directory found in install/ . For our example, the path to our include files looks like: ros2env_rootdir/install/hello_world_pkg/include

Finally, we’ll use ament_cmake, which is the build system for C++ packages in ROS2, to make our package discoverable to other ROS2 packages. The last line is essential to the entire CML file because it generates configuration files and setup scripts. It also registers our package in the ROS2 workspace, allowing us to actually run the node.

89ament_export_include_directories(include)
90ament_export_libraries(${PROJECT_NAME}_lib)
91ament_export_dependencies(rclcpp std_msgs)
92
93# Last line of the CML file
94ament_package()

Now you should be able to write, build, and run your own C++ packages in ROS2 without CMake semantics slowing you down! Simply substitute your directory and file names for the names used in this example.
